subSense.example:
Models twirled
round on the catwalk

She twisted the
string round a piece of stick

The path twisted
between the fields

There are
only two peppermints left in the box

His son's only two (years old), so he
can't read yet

She didn't come home
until after two (o'clock)

subSense.def:
a group of people, ani-
mals or things that are similar to each
other
subSense.example:
This type of bank account pays
10% interest

What type of accommo-
dation are you looking for?

subSense.def:
to
write with a computer or typewriter
subSense.example:
Please type your letters -your writing's
so bad I can't read it

She only typed
two lines and made six mistakes

subSense.def:
a machine
which prints letters or numbers on a
piece of paper when keys are pressed

having the
usual qualities of a particular group or
occasion
subSense.example:
Describe a typical day at
school

He's definitely not a typical
bank manager

subSense.def:
a ring made of rubber
which is put round a wheel
subSense.example:
Check the
pressure in the car tyres before starting
a journey

They used an old tyre to
make a seat for the garden swing

subSense.def:
the twenty-first letter of
the alphabet, between T and V

body.subSense:
unpleasant to look
at ć What an ugly pattern! ć The part of
the town round the railway station is
even uglier than the rest. (NOTE: uglier
-ugliest)

subSense.example:
Exports from
the UK or UK exports rose last year

subSense.def:
a round
frame covered with cloth which you
hold over your head to keep off the rain
subSense.example: Can I borrow your umbrella?

As it
was starting to rain, he opened his um-
brella

The wind blew my umbrella in-
side out

body.subSense:
not able to
do something ć I regret that I am unable
to accept your suggestion. ć She was
unable to come to the meeting. (NOTE:
be unable to is a rather formal way of
saying can't.)

subSense.example:
Her husband is a rather
unattractive man

The house is unat-
tractive from the outside

subSense.def:
so bad that you cannot accept it or deal
with it

subSense.example:
She is uncertain
whether to accept the job

He's uncer-
tain about what to do next

Their
plans are still uncertain

subSense.def:
a brother of your
father or mother
subSense.example:
He was brought up
by his uncle in Scotland

We had a
surprise visitor last night -old Uncle
Charles

What a very
uncomfortable bed!

Plastic seats are
very uncomfortable in hot weather

subSense.def:
not saying
much, or not answering people

easy to deal with or under-
stand
subSense.example:
In children's books, the writing
should be clear and uncomplicated

The procedure is relatively quick and
uncomplicated

subSense.def:
in
a physical condition in which you are
not aware of what is happening
subSense.example:
He
was found unconscious in the street

She was unconscious for two days after
the accident

subSense.def:
in or to a
place where something else is on top or
above
subSense.example: We all hid under the table
My pen rolled under the sofa

It took under two
weeks to sell the house

The train goes
to Paris in under three hours

Under
half of the members turned up for the
meeting

The old table sold for under
£10

The ordinary rail-
way line goes underground for a short
distance

Worms live all their life un-
derground

There's an underground pas-
sage to the tower

The hotel has an un-
derground car park

subSense.def:
a
railway in a town, which runs under the
ground
subSense.example:
Thousands of people use the
underground to go to work

Take the
underground to go to Oxford Circus

It's usually quicker to get across town
by underground
subSense.note:
NOTE: The London
Underground is often called the Tube.
In the United States, an underground
railway is called a subway

subSense.def:
to write a line under a
word or figure
subSense.example:
He wrote the title and
then underlined it in red

She wore a long green jumper
underneath her coat

Can you see if
my pen is underneath the sofa?

He put the box of books
down on the kitchen table and my sand-
wiches were underneath

Don't
try to talk English to Mr Yoshida -he
doesn't understand it

subSense.def:
to have sympa-
thy for someone
subSense.example:
She's a good teacher
-she really understands children

body.subSense:
3. to
know why something happens or how
something works ć I can easily under-
stand why his wife left him. ć I still
don't understand how to operate the
new laser printer. (NOTE: understands
-understanding -understood
/ ndə stυd/)

subSense.example:
My understanding of how the Internet
works is severely limited

subSense.def:
sympathy
for someone else and their problems
subSense.example:
The boss showed no understanding
when she told him about her financial
difficulties

The aim is to promote un-
derstanding between the two countries

We reached an
understanding with the lawyers

The
understanding was that we would all go
to the office after lunch

His understanding atti-
tude was much appreciated

subSense.def: below the surface of the water
subSense.example:
How
long can you stay underwater?

He
dived and swam underwater for several
seconds

She goes on holiday to the
Red Sea to do underwater photography

body.subSense:
clothes
worn next to your skin under other
clothes (NOTE: no plural)

to open something
which is tied or fastened ć The first
thing he did on getting home was to
undo his tie. ć Undo your top button if
your collar is too tight. (NOTE: undoes
/ n d z/ -undid / n dd/ -undone
/ n d n/)

subSense.def:
having
just taken off your clothes
subSense.example:
The chil-
dren are getting undressed ready for
bed
Are you undressed yet

The government is en-
couraging unemployed teenagers to ap-
ply for training grants

The unemploy-
ment figures or the figures for unem-
ployment are rising

subSense.def:
which is surprising and not what was
expected
subSense.example:
We had an unexpected visit
from the police

His failure was quite
unexpected

It's
unfair to expect her to do all the house-
work while her sisters don't lift a finger
to help

It was very un-
fortunate that she couldn't come to see
us

subSense.def: which you wish was not true
subSense.example:
Un-
fortunately the train arrived so late that
she missed the meeting

body.subSense:
not
acting like a friend (NOTE: unfriendlier
-unfriendliest)
